<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetHostName:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(name_len);

    /* delegate to low-level API */
    return_code = OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(host_name, name_len);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return an empty string on failure, just in case */
        host_name[0] = 0;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_NetworkGetHostName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    if (gethostname(host_name, name_len) < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * posix does not say that the name is always
         * null terminated, so its worthwhile to ensure it
         */
        host_name[name_len - 1] = 0;
        return_code             = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no fragments that modify a function parameter variable itself. All assignments in the code write to the object pointed to by the pointer parameters (e.g., host_name[0] = 0 and host_name[name_len - 1] = 0), which is explicitly allowed by Rule 17.8. There are no reassignments to the pointer parameters (no statements like host_name = ... or name_len = ...). The macros OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name) and OS_CHECK_SIZE(name_len) expand to checks (BUGCHECK/ARGCHECK) that do not perform assignments to the parameters. The precondition checks (OS_CHECK_POINTER and OS_CHECK_SIZE) ensure host_name is non-NULL and name_len > 0, so the index writes cannot underflow or dereference NULL. Therefore no code fragments need investigation for violations of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
